comments.commentBody: Britain's the world's oldest liberal democracy, and its prevailing national identity after World War II has been based on anti-fascism. The BNP know that Britons would never allow a party that explicitly called itself fascist to be in power. So how do we know that they are nonetheless a fascist party? It conflates citizenship with racial identity; it blatantly advocates white supremacy; it is anti-Semitic; it appeals to fear and ethnically based hatred. By the way, Hitler was voted in as chancellor in a free election, and the British Union of Fascists in the 1930s--with as many as 40,000 members at its height--also put up many candidates under its banner, hoping to be brought into power through the parliamentary system. The BNP isn't the first fascist party to equivocate with the vote in order to demolish democracy. It is trying to tempt people to agree to the annihilation of their own rights.
So, Mr. Bragg wants to "fight for the soul of the English people".  If immigration to the UK continues unchecked, before too long there won't be any ethnic English people left.

In fact, you can treat a clown but this guy is just reacting at the American and European Actions toward his country. It's just a political fight and if you're so sure that your events of 11/9, why would make a step in the back ? I mean in the last crisis or world wars, we've wait 40-50 years at less, like in the death of famous president JFK with still secret veiling the history, or today we aim that we are developping nations but in fact, we would continue to wait 50 years again for see and mesure the reality ? We can expose ourself straight now to the reality and the skeptical aspect must be verify during the time that it is still fresh for the details and comparison. After that, I think America and European Union would have more worth for tackle Iran on the Political's Faith of his gouvernment.

Hey Feanor @2:

Protecting the indigenous white population? Are you joking? I hope you're aware that Britain is the product of waves of invaders and immigrants, even before the so-called "white" race existed. I'm sure the stone age inhabitants of the island really related to their Celtic conquerors, who I'm sure were absolutely in love with the Germanic Saxons who displaced them, who themselves probably relished being conquered by the Normans. There is no "pure" white indigenous British race; like every other European grouping, they're genetic mutts, and the idea that the BNP are protecting indigenous Britons is irrational, pseudo-scientific and incredibly racist. Leave it up to white trash in the States, still pining for Jim Crow and racial quotas, to throw their weight behind it.

Ben,

Ben, you are completely correct. Being legitimately elected has nothing at all to do with not being a fascist.

Interesting you mentioned Zimbabwe, Fascist Paul. I assume you have a particular grievance with your former colonial subjects for their having given white people the same sort of (wrong) treatment that you previously had subjected them to for nearly a century.
All You Fascists Bound To Lose!
Thank goodness for Billy Bragg.  We need a cultural figure like him here, who is not afraid to call for democratic socialism.  That's the only way to stop fascism for once and for all.

Like Billy Bragg explains in the video: "The people in Barking and Dagenham's concerns must be addressed. There are genuine concerns that must be addressed. But not by racist fascism. They must be addressed like they've always been addressed - by democratic socialism"

This is true of communities all over the world. Especially during rough economic times, people become frustrated and unable to vent their frustration through typical political routes. Fascism isn't the solution - it's an opportunistic philosophy that preys on political and social insecurity.

The solution is community involvement, organizing, grassroots struggle to bring attention to the situation and to TRULY address human concerns.

I think you will find that that news organization makes liberal use of the convention in its headlines. The point is that there is a convention, something called "quotation marks," and we cannot write headlines for people who do not know what they are. This post is exactly about the campaign by people who call the B.N.P. "fascists," so the headline is perfectly accurate. If other news organizations write about the people calling President Obama a "Marxist" and use the same convention, that would also be correct.

The wider point is about when it is responsible to do that, which is a fair question. Here's my answer: when there is evidence to support the use of the term in question by the group one is writing about. In this case, there is ample evidence of B.N.P. support for fascism - in, for example, public statements by the party's leader, Nick Griffin, that Hitler "went a bit too far," that "There is a strong, direct link from Oswald Mosley to me," and that "Britain does not have the tradition of intellectual fascism which is such an important factor in many other countries. While I do have a number of proposals to help rectify this deficiency, the truth is that this is a handicap which we can never overcome completely." In the case of people calling President Obama a Marxist, there is no apparent evidence at all.

Robert Mackey
"The headline is accurate: it says the party has been called fascist, which is why that word is in quotes."

Interesting reasoning. Does this mean a headline in a media outlet (let’s say FoxNews) like - ““Marxist” president signs American nukes away" - in reference to President Obama signing an arms reduction treaty, is accurate? After all Obama “has been called” Marxist.

My understanding is that Fascism happens only in democracies. First, a minority party—the Fascists—bully the other parties or largest party into submission, all by alleging public support. They then take over the government, having completely bullied the opposition out and install their own government. The rest is history.

Of course, we know this can't happen in the US, however dangerous it is in Britain.

#2, Feanor:

"The BNP is merely standing up for the rights of the indigenous White British, who in a few decades will be a minority in their own lands. There is nothing wrong with that, especially considering every other group has dozens of organizations looking out for them."

What is the spirit of the British people? It is certainly not those who wish to exclude and expel and do not tolerate.

There are plenty of people who are more British, in terms of national character, than people who are British, according to some intellectually bankrupt definition: genetics. Over 50 years ago, hundred of thousands of real British died fighting the same failed ideology you espouse that had taken over Germany.

What you are describing is the opposite of being British, what you espouse is the downfall of Britain, what you espouse is hate.
It sounds like Nick Griffin has all the qualifications necessary to be the president of Iran.

Hey - Obama can put a stop to this nonsense by apologizing to the entire world for the misdeeds of the previous administration and that the 9/11 was never conspired by 'foreign enemy combatants'. Do you think the Iranian lunatic will be satisfied?

The point is that there is a convention, something called "quotation marks," and we cannot write headlines for people who do not know what they are. This post is exactly about the campaign by people who call the B.N.P. "fascists," so the headline is perfectly accurate.

The wider point is about when it is responsible to do that, which is a fair question. Here's my answer: when there is evidence to support the use of the term in question by the group one is writing about. In this case, there is ample evidence of B.N.P. support for fascism - in, for example, public statements by the party's leader, Nick Griffin, that Hitler "went a bit too far," that "There is a strong, direct link from Oswald Mosley to me," and that "Britain does not have the tradition of intellectual fascism which is such an important factor in many other countries. While I do have a number of proposals to help rectify this deficiency, the truth is that this is a handicap which we can never overcome completely."

I concede that a fascist party can be democratically elected, Gordon's Brown Labour party for example, is a fascist party and it has been democratically elected.

However, although me and others consider the Labour party a fascist party, I doubt very much the NYtimes is ever going to make a headline saying Labour 'fascist' party, it doesn't sound like very impartial to me Mr Rober Mackey.

I see that everyone is skipping over the issue that BNP party members are not allowed to join the police force in Britain. There is a law against this, part of the Labour 'fascist' party strategy to get rid of political opponents.

I invite everyone to Google for the British National Party website and make up their own mind based on what they say there and not based on what some partial journalist can say here.

Since you are making that comment from New York, you seem to agree with Mr. Bragg that to have an interest in what happens in his hometown, where his mother still lives, you do not need to reside there.

Btw, I'd like to mention, that while Billy Bragg campaigns against the BNP, he himself has moved to white middle class Dorset, an all middle-class white neighborhood. Tell me, if he loves Dagenham and the neighborhood he came from so much, why doesn't he just live there?

On the whole, I agree with Jeff Sweet. On the other hand, there was an excruciating evening of juvenalia in the form of the JERRY SPRINGER OPERA. Jesus wears diapers. Vaguely Handel-like bits of musical business. Inane and deliberately offensive frat boy humor. Sweeney Todd is Dantesque in stature in comparison with this drivel.... Five minutes of ABFAB or Slings and Arrows or Coraline had more wit and craft. I have no problem with a noble failure but this was just archness and blue language masquerading as a play--opera? I guess the mere idea that the Jerry Springer show could be an opera was supposed to cause one to fall on the floor in fits of admiration for it's audacious premise.... And I say that as a person who can make a longshoreman blush. In short, Copperfield--I didn't like it.
Bond is really a hero,but only can  a miraculous story contiune the legendary hero.
Who cares? Time to end the Bond franchise.

I had a reaction similar to Carmen's with regard to the demise of Tom Shays. It was horrible, but I understand that it happened to make a point. Tom made a very bad decision in following the money. He gave in to pressure from his wife (and wasn't she a supportive spouse) and assumed financial burdens he never should have assumed, all in the name of keeping up with his peers and, not incidentally, of greed.

He learned, the hard way, that when it comes to large sums of money, you have no friends. It's a lesson he should have been learning from Patty, but apparently he thought himself above such things, and that fatal flaw was his undoing. To my mind, what was done to Tom is a reflection of the whole point of this show: it is, after all, called "Damages." And will Ellen learn from this awful incident? I doubt it. She is, in a way, responsible for what happened to Tom: she and Tom would have been wiser to follow Patty's instructions, but they thought they were capable of taking matters into their own hands.

The lesson here is that pride, greed and ambition are not for amateurs. Playing hardball can hurt. People do stupid and terrible things for money, and sometimes end up losing everything. This season proved that in spades. Tom was a victim, Ellen was damaged but survived, and Patty remains, so far, undefeated.

Although most of us here have agreed that the finale was too crammed with resolutions, at least there were credible and reasonably satisfying resolutions to the situations set up during the season. All too many of today's TV dramas simply don't bother keeping things logical, and I appreciate the dramatic integrity of "Damages." I do hope we can continue to count on that.

How about a sense of humor as in SEAN CONNERY?  Remember, Ian Fleming originally based the character on Cary Grant.  It's a good idea to go back to Cary Grant's best films to rejuvenate the character's wit.  The next step would be to find some original CGI people so the action looks fresh.  Then have Daniel Craig stop clenching his teeth and pursing his lips.  It gets tiresome after a while.
As Joe notes above, it can indeed mean that the actor wants out.  But for a show being delayed a year, it can also mean:  the actor needs to work to eat ...
Of course not. Women that thin don't put dressing on their salads.

Adam (#5)  and Rebecca (#47): The NYT still listed Mr. Duranty in their full page, self-congratulatory list of all the NYT reporters who had won the prize: "1932, Walter Duranty, for his coverage of Russia" -- not even "the Soviet Union," which is what he covered so abysmally. Maybe they're not quite as embarrassed as they were a few years ago.
I have a robe made from the same fabric. Wanna see pics?

I'm tee'd out of late, but in Malcolm McLaren's honor, I will definitely make some joyful noise at the appropriate moment. He was a unique and amazingly prescient man who kicked the cultural status quo in the rump and set it on a whole new course. Hope he and Lee McQueen are having a rollicking good time somewhere in the universe, along with Issie Blow - perhaps the three of them are rockin' out and shakin' up the nearby harp players with a little Sex Pistols medley! I hope so.

Cheers, all!
